This weekly bulletin informs students, parents, and staff about internships, academic
programs, jobs, community service options, and leadership initiatives, along with
other student opportunities in a variety of fields. Please carefully note deadlines, age
requirements, and other pre-requisites for participation.
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
Service, and so on.
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
the Stuy community!
Now that we are into the month of May, students should check these still-available
opportunities and submit applications – many programs have rapidly approaching
deadlines – several are highlighted below:
EVENTS: All students are welcome to register for free after-school dance classes at
Stuy, offered by outstanding instructors from the Battery Dance Group. Sample
sessions in Hip Hop, AfroBeat, Modern, & other dance styles are available, and
continue throughout the month of May - students with any level of expertise, from
beginners to expert, are welcome to join!
The New York Hall of Science in Queens welcomes all students to its May 17 th
STEM Career Expo, at which participants will meet STEM professionals from a
variety of fields.
ACADEMICS: The STEM Institute at City College in Manhattan offers a variety of
STEM-focused summer classes for current 9th, 10th, and 11th graders – the application
deadline is May 6th!
BUSINESS/JOBS: Two new free summer accounting programs are open to all
interested students who want to learn more about this profession. And the Museum of
Finance’s free virtual business classes for current 11th and 12th graders begin soon!
COMMUNITY SERVICE: The Margaret Tietz Nursing & Rehabilitation Center
in Queens offers a variety of summer volunteer opportunities for all students with an
interest in health care.
LEADERSHIP/GOVERNMENT: The Chinatown Community Builders program
develops helpful community projects, and is open to all 9th and 10th graders. And the
leadership-development Sadie Nash Summer Institute program welcomes
applications from all women and gender-expansive students – the deadline is May
10th.
WRITING/PERFORMING ARTS: Sound Thinking is a free summer Music Career
program for current 9th, 10th, and 11th graders – it can lead to a paid music industry
internship for participants in the summer of 2025; the application deadline is May
6th!.

Priority Deadline Today: Fordham University STEP Summer Program
“The Fordham Science and Technology Entry Program (STEP) is an academic
enrichment program, established in 1986, designed to prepare underrepresented
minority and economically disadvantaged junior high and high school students for
college and careers in STEM fields (science, technology, engineering, and math)

social work among other licensed fields.”

and science courses of underrepresented groups (Black/African Americans,
Hispanics/Latinxs, Native American Indians, and Alaskan Natives) OR economically
disadvantaged students

Location: Lincoln Center Campus, Manhattan OR Rose Hill Campus, Bronx

Deadline Approaching: Brown University Pre-College Programs
“Brown University allows high school students the opportunity to get a feel for
college life by experiencing college-level academics while exploring a unique subject
area of interest. Through Summer@Brown, students will be able to explore new
paths with the choice of over 200 non-credit courses. Through the Brown Leadership
Institute, students will be able to increase their abilities and effectiveness in
advancing social justice. Through the Brown Environmental Leadership Lab
program at various locations, students will embark on a journey of learning and
reflection while building community with fellow student environmentalists. Through
the Location-Based programs, students will be able to immerse themselves in
foreign languages and cultures while studying at partner universities. Through the
STEM for Rising 9th and 10th Graders program, students will advance their
knowledge of the STEM disciplines while completing hands-on team research
projects, experiments, and design-build challenges. Through the Pre-Baccalaureate
program, rising and recently graduated high school seniors will take on the rigors of
credit-bearing, undergraduate study.”
Eligible: Current freshmen (limited to the STEM program), sophomores (generally
limited to Summer@Brown, the Leadership Institute, and the Brown Environmental
Leadership Labs), juniors, and seniors

“John Hopkins Engineering Innovation Pre-College Programs welcomes talented math
and science students interested in engineering this summer. Programs include studying

mechanical, materials science, and biomedical engineering. Online, in-person, and
residential programs are offered. Join the program staff and other students to discuss
the incredible on-hands labs and activities you will experience,
details about the admissions process, and college credit information.”

“During the course,
students complete activities in civil, chemical, electrical/computer,
mechanical engineering, and materials science. By applying knowledge of math

classrooms are linked to real-world practice. Additionally, students’

theories, and ultimately learn to think like engineers.”

3.    Sustainable Energy Engineering (SEE)
“How can we design and
implement new sustainable energy technologies that are resilient and
economical, and that may be incorporated into the existing power grid? To
answer these questions, we need to take a deep look the ways we currently use
energy so that we may find ways to reduce our use, and we must study the
science and engineering concepts behind our current methods of energy
production and distribution, as well as the impact of policy on our ability to
make change. This course will introduce students to these topics, giving
them the fundamental knowledge necessary to understand the challenges and
opportunities in sustainable energy engineering, and to decide whether this is
a field they want to pursue.”
Eligible: Current sophomores and juniors, and seniors (exceptional freshmen
may be considered, but will have less priority)

intellectual leaders. Hundreds of thousands of our students have gone on to attend

World Scholars Academy Elite Summer Courses & Internships
“Our online summer courses are taught by instructors from top universities who
introduce students to what it is like to undertake advanced study in their chosen
discipline. You will work both one-on-one with your instructor and in a small group

leading expert in their field. On your internship you will coauthor an original research

expert mentor, allowing you to become a published author when you submit your
completed research paper to our open-access academic journal or an external scholarly
publication.”
